text: there's nothing that seems to get you in
the holiday spirit more than a little
cookie baking but when it comes to
decorating those cookies a lot of you
have been reaching out and asking us
what is the best way to decorate cookies
and how to make the perfect royal icing
well today I'm going to show you just
how to do that and it's a lot simpler
than you think now I have a large wide
Bowl here and to that I'm going to add a
half of a cup of meringue powder
meringue powder is something that you
can get at a baking shop a specialty
shop and all it is is dried egg white
with a little bit of sugar added to it
and sometimes it has flavoring like
vanilla it's a very very fine powder and
to that add one cup of water and now
using my hand blender here with the
whisk attachment I'm going to whip up my
egg white powder to a nice soft peak so
make sure that you scrape down the sides
of the bowl a little bit whipping the
egg white powder helps to prevent
clumping usually if you just dump all of
the ingredients together sometimes you
end up with a clumpy royal icing well
this process really helps in dissolving
the egg white powder and it will end up
being really fluffy so our mixture is at
soft peaks I'm going to change the
attachment from the whisk to the paddle
attachment now you can do this in your
stand mixer as well starting with the
whisk attachment and then moving to the
paddle and I'm going to add now two
pounds of confectioner sugar so that's
two boxes and on the lowest speed gently
start to stir this together
so now for a little bit of flavoring I'm
going to add two teaspoons of lemon
juice you could use vanilla extract here
as well that looks right and just gently
mix this together
in terms of consistency what you're
looking for is something like Elmer's
glue a fluffy Elmer's glue the way I
like to gauge the texture is just to
pull up the beaters you should have a
ribbon of royal icing and it should melt
almost immediately into the rest of the
royal icing and that's when you know the
consistency is right so look for that
Elmer's glue thick Elmer's glue and it
holds a line before falling back into
itself so this is ready to go and we're
ready to decorate our cookies so now for
the fun part the decorating I don't
really like to use pastry bags and
pastry tips because I think they're a
little unwieldy I like to use these
squeeze bottles and they're really great
because you can control the motion I
have a thin tip here this is probably a
number two tip if you were using a
pastry tip and this is a little bit
wider this is a number 3 tip here I'm
gonna start with something simple this
nice stocking and with the thin tip I'm
going to create a border and this is
called the dam and working about a
quarter of an inch away from the side of
the cookie pipe your icing and now with
the wider tip here I'm going to fill in
the interior of the box that I just
created and this is called flooding and
the reason why I like this royal icing
recipe so much is because it's so
voluminous and it's thick it doesn't
become runny and pour off the sides of
the cookie now I'm using a toothpick
here to blend in any of the spaces and
then to even out the icing because you
can see it's raised in certain spots
give the cookie a little bit of a shake
and it should even out perfectly now to
embellish the royal icing a little bit
I'd like to use sanding sugars
especially around the holidays I'm using
some fine sanding sugar here and
sprinkle it directly over the top of the
royal icing and this technique is called
flocking now you could use sprinkles you
could use nonpareils coarse sanding
sugar fine sanding sugar colored sugar
anything you'd like and you just have to
let the cookie sit now for at least five
minutes before you shake off the excess
sugar so I'm going to keep decorating
and now for a Christmas tree again it's
the same idea where you're create
outlined with a thin tip and you can see
I don't have the point of the tip on the
cookie itself it's lifted up slightly
giving a quarter-inch border is very
important and now to fill in using the
wider tip so this again is called
flooding if you wanted to make it a
little bit thinner it does make it a
little bit easier and faster to get
through this process especially if
you're baking dozens of cookies for the
holiday season it just spreads out a
little bit faster it's very important
that when you're creating the dam or the
outline that the royal icing be stiff so
you don't want it to be too too loose
and you can really embellish these
cookies in any way you'd like you can
add little candies to this Christmas
tree to make ornaments again give it a
little bit of shake to even out that
icing I'm going to continue on with the
same process and just give it that
really bright and shiny sanding sugar
and I'm going to keep going with these
cookies until I have them all done so
after your cookies dry preferably
overnight brush away any of the sanding
sugar that's in between in all those
nooks and crannies and there you have it
decorated cookies 101 how to make your
royal icing and how to decorate you'll
be decorating cookies all holiday season
with these tips
enjoy
